Here's my tough take aways on this con=
vo:

   - A RESTful system has a shared set of responsibilities between cli=
ent
   and server. To truly realize the benefits of REST both client and se=
rver
   have to be good citizens.
   - The server is the critical path. It'=
s responsibility is to expose
   resources in a manner that is consistent w=
ith adhering to the constraints.
   That means it sticks to the uniform int=
erface (headers, media types),
   supports caching, uses hypermedia etc.
  =
 - The client must also adhere to REST constraints. If it does not, then
  =
 the overall benefits of REST are not achieved within that system. It's
   =
responsibility is to consume resources in a RESTful manner, i.e. use the
  =
 uniform interface, consumes hypermedia, obeys caching requirements, etc.
 =
  - A client not obeying the rules does not necessarily remove all
   benef=
its of REST for the server, though it can if it is the ONLY client.
   - No=
t enough emphasis is put on this division of responsibilities when
   talki=
ng about REST.

Thoughts?

Thanks
Glenn

<li>The =

<li>The client must also adhere to REST const=

      <p>Fine then, Glenn, here it is plain answer:<br>
<br>
a. =
Yes if you define RESTFulness as a badge that certifies you follow the rule=
s. Yes, you can earn that badge only in your server and forget about the cl=
ient.<br>
<br>
b. NO, if you define RESTFulness as the achievement of the e=
xpected quality properties you seek for when using REST. And that NO is bec=
ause the rules are made to achieve a way of interaction between the compone=
nts, and one of those components is the client. <br>

<br>
In other words, =
client matters.<br>
<br>
As I had been posting here, one component may not =
behave by the rules, but if that is free license the architect is aware of =
and it is reasonable so that the impact will not break the business goals, =
that is fine. But if you need a system where clients behave correctly, and =
you don't control the clients, then your architecture must have control=
s and policy enforcement to avoid those spoiled clients from ruining you da=
y. If not, your system will not get to its goal and it will be a failure, e=
ven if your server is made by the REST book. <br>

<br>
REST stops when it =
defines the constrains and promises quality properties, but life goes on, a=
nd the rest of the system is still to be constructed. Having just one serve=
r following REST rules is just one step. And let me clarify this: It should=
 not be part of the server's job to assure the client is working as it =
should. It may help, but we can have several layers that can add controls a=
nd enforce policies. There is far more in an system than just one server an=
d one client.<br>

<br>
Finally: I feel the discussion confuses an App, wit=
h a Server, with a System, with a API. When we talk about a server doing it=
s part, sounds like we are talking about an API. Is it that? Yes, we can ex=
pose a REST like API, but then we need a client to consume it. A system is =
something far more complex, where all components, including clients, may af=
fect other components. Butterfly effect, that is called.<br>

<br>
Well, th=
is was not a short and sweet answer, and I feel I'm repeating myself he=
re. But it is truly a more deep discussion than just earning a badge.<br>
<=
br>
Cheers<br>
<br>
William.</p><div class=3D"im"><br>
